Budget deficit cut,
Tuition hike forseen
By DON LASSUS
Increases in federal and state
aid an a contraction in the Arts
and Sciences faculty have helped
to cut the Hopkins fiscal deficit
in half for the second year in a
row.
The $95 million budget for the
aI 972-73 fiscal year includes a
deficit of a pproximately $1
million representing the second
significant cut in the deficit in
Iwo years.
According to President Muller
the reduction in the fiscal deficit
is due primarily to increases in
federal and state aid and a freeze
in hiring new faculty to replace
retiring faculty members.
Muller stated that under the
! faculty contraction policy the
Arts and Sciences faculty has
dropped by fifteen to twenty
members.
The policy also includes the
consolidation of departments
such as the new Department of
Mathematical Sciences.
"We're not asking anyone to
leave," Muller stressed. "We're
just not replacing the faculty
members who do leave the
University."
Grants
Besides receiving its annual
$350,000 grant from the state.
Hopkins will see an increase in
. federal aid to the Medical School
under the new Health Manpower
Education Act.
Muller noted that the Medical

School will operate without any
deficit this year with the
$800,000 grant from the federal
government. He also indicated
that the School for Advanced
International Studies.(SAIS) will
also operate without a fiscal
deficit for 1972-73 due to
in creases in small foundation
grants.
Reductions in the Arts and
Sciences deficit were aided by
the admission of 200 more
undergraduates as well as some
small cuts operating budget costs,
said Muller.
Balanced Budget
The University President
expressed hope for a balanced
budget for Hopkins in the next
fiscal year but stated that an
increase in undergraduate tuition
would be necessary to achieve
that end. The amount of the
increase in tuition has yet to be
determined but will take affect in
the fall of 1973.
Hopkins operated under a
balanced budget until the
1 968-69 fiscal year when
inflation and dwindling revenues
began to put the University into
debt. The deficits increased over
the ensuing years reaching a high
of over $4 million in 1970-71.
Cutbacks in administrative
spending, a strict economic
policy and an increase in
revenues contributed to cut
down the deficit over the past
two years to $I million.

Phi Gam expects to be reinstated
New Dean of Students Robert
Fitzpatrick is expected to grant
"provisional recognition" .this
week to the ousted Hopkins
chapter of the Phi Gamma Delta
fraternity.
The University withdrew its
official "recognition" of the
fraternity, including the privilage
of "rushing" oh campus, in wake
of a large outdoor party held on
the grounds of the Phi Gamma
Delta house on Canterbury Road
last June.
Loss Party
The party, following Hopkins'
loss to Virginia .in the Lacrosses
championships, apparently
degenerated into an all night
drinking fest which resulted in
considerable damage to the
fraternity house.
Although only 15 of the

estimated 300 late night revelers
were Phi Gamma Delta brothers,
letters from irate neighbors and a
damaging article by The Morning
Sun prompted University
officials to take action against.
the fraternity. Fitzpatrick, City
Councilman from the Second
District, who had not yet been
appointed Dean, stated that his
office was swamped with
complaints from everybody from
"U.S. Senator Charles Mathias on
down."
Both Fitzpatrick and Phi
Gamma Delta President John
Gibson expect that the fraternity
will be allowed back on campus.
'If we recognize the
Fraternity, I will get a lot of hell
from my constituency,'' said
Fitzpatrick, "but 'we can't
operate in a vaccuum." In the

future, Fitzpatrick hopes that his
office will act as a "preventative
measure" against similar
problems.
Phi Gamma Delta President
John Gibson is also optimistic
about the future but he remains
disappointed about newspaper
coverage of the incident. In
. particular, Gibson is angered over
la quote in the June 6th
Sun/Japers article stating that the
'party left the house completely
"The
''unrepairable.'
Sunpapers' article was very
amusing but very exaggerated,"
said Gibson.
Cost
Following the Sunpapers
article and the community
outcry against the fraternity, city
building and fire •inspectdrs

ordered Phi Gamma Delta to
engage building contractors
within five days to repair the
house so that it conformed with
Baltimore City fire and housing
regulations. According to Gibson,
who was not present at the party,
these repairs are costing the
fraternity over S10,000 while the
actual damage done to the house
during the party ammounted to
only a few hundred dollars.
But if the incident hurt the
fraternity, it equally damaged the
University with 'respect to
housing, according to
Fitzpatrick. He noted the
unwillingness of many
Homewood area landlords to
enter into "guaranteed lease
arrangements" with Hopkins
students because of the Phi
Gamma Delta incident.
